awd_titl_txt: Commemorating 20 Years of ADVANCE: Design Thinking Sessions for a Digital Exhibit and Archive
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will convene members of the ADVANCE community to develop and launch prototypes of an exhibit and archive commemorating 20 years of NSF ADVANCE. The in-person focus groups will take place at the 2022 ARC Network Equity in STEM Community Convening, which serves as the biennial meeting of the ADVANCE community, with the virtual focus group immediately following the Convening. The meetings will be conducted as collaborative brainstorming using design thinking to seek broad input on content creation, distribution, and evaluation for the exhibit and archive. Inputs gleaned from the 2022 Community Convening will be refined afterward through an online focus group and participatory webinar to reach those members of the ADVANCE community who were not in attendance. In this way the broader ADVANCE community will co-create the framework for the archive and thereby generate shared ownership.

The intellectual merit of this conference proposal lies in its focus on rendering visible the contributions of the diverse individuals that have designed, implemented, evaluated, and researched ADVANCE projects over the last 20 years.  This effort is designed to capture and share the contribution of these teams and individuals to gender equity work in STEM.  This project will also share knowledge on how organizational and institutional change occurred as a direct result of NSF ADVANCE awards.  The creation and dissemination of this digital archive is intended to enhance the impact of all ADVANCE projects by highlighting the diverse composition and participation of people in these activities. This includes capturing the longitudinal career impact on people of having participated in ADVANCE.  

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since 2001, the National Science Foundation’s ADVANCE: Organizational Change for Gender Equity in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Academic Professions program has supported more than 200 institutions of higher education and STEM-related non-profit organizations in contributing to the NSF's goal of a more diverse and capable science and engineering workforce. As NSF ADVANCE celebrated it's 20th anniversary, we sought to create an ADVANCE digital storytelling exhibit that would 1) make visible the contributions and personal and professional experiences of the many people doing intersectional gender equity work in academic STEM, 2) share processes by which organizational, institutional, and systemic change have been made possible through ADVANCE, and 3) highlight the outcomes and challenges of ADVANCE work, allowing changemakers to build on lessons learned.

This conference proposal, led by current and former ADVANCE investigators, set out to inform the exhibit design in collaboration with the broader ADVANCE and intersectional gender equity in STEM communities. From 2022-2024, we gathered feedback from a wide range of constituents through several different mechanisms. First, at the 2022 ADVANCE Equity in STEM Community Convening in Washington, DC, we hosted four on-site design-thinking focus group sessions and, following the Convening, we held two sessions via Zoom. We sought input about exhibit content, how it would be experienced, its desired functionality and audiences, and potential purposes and outcomes. We also inquired about how participating in ADVANCE had impacted participating individuals, their institutions, and the broader STEM community as well as about their project and career timelines. Forty-six participants shared their perspectives through these initial sessions, which guided the creation of our first mid-fidelity exhibit prototype. This prototype was a tagged, searchable website containing video and narrative artifacts that were categorized thematically.

Next, at the 2023 ADVANCE Equity in STEM Community Convening in Durham, NC, we presented our findings and prototype in an interactive session that invited twenty-two attendees to contribute additional feedback and perspectives.  These valuable contributions allowed us to further refine our thinking and design. We also continued to analyze and incorporate feedback we collected from dozens of attendees at the conferences we attended throughout the year. Finally, at the 2024 ADVANCE Equity in STEM Community Convening in Baltimore, MD, we shared the culmination of this work as a poster session. The poster contained a QR code for a community input survey where attendees shared additional ideas with us.

Taken together, we learned much from community members about their hopes and fears related to an ADVANCE digital storytelling exhibit. In terms of exhibit design and functionality, members of the community encouraged us to prioritize accessibility, user-friendliness, interactive multimedia content allowing for many forms of engagement, and ease of navigation. They also wanted to see the exhibit serve many target audiences, including faculty and administrators, scholars in and of academic STEM, postdocs, graduate students, funders, STEM professional societies, and changemakers. Community members sought content highlighting the personal and professional stories of participating in ADVANCE work, the impacts and return on investment of ADVANCE funding, past and ongoing challenges, connections between stories and curated resources, and ways for researchers and practitioners to collaborate. Across the community, there was a strong desire to authentically share both the opportunities and the challenges of ADVANCE. Community members shared much about how their personal and professional journeys were situated in relation to change and resistance to change. Lastly, within the current legislative and political climate, we heard fears about the risks that can accompany greater online visibility which led us to incorporate mechanisms for privacy and anonymous storytelling into our design plans.

The intellectual merit of this conference proposal resides in its focus on rendering visible the wide range of contributions and contributors to intersectional gender equity work in STEM, the processes by which organizational and institutional change occurred as a direct result of an NSF ADVANCE award, and the challenges and lessons learned. Using a participatory design framework to guide the selection, recruitment, and involvement of a breadth of participants in design thinking focus group sessions and community input fora supported the initial design plans for a digital storytelling exhibit that reflect a diverse ADVANCE community.

This project has several areas of broader impact. First, by leveraging prior NSF ADVANCE and Directorate for STEM Education Core Research (ECR: Core) awards, we build on the lessons learned from and elevate the broader impacts of those awards. Second, the creation and dissemination of this digital storytelling exhibit is likely to enhance societal impact of the ADVANCE program itself by highlighting the breadth of contributions and contributors to ADVANCE, and better understanding and articulating the return on investment of ADVANCE. Further, in sharing the longitudinal career impact on and trajectories of people of having participated in ADVANCE, we broaden our collective understanding of the range of STEM and STEM-related career pathways.
